comment.author: 69005233@N00
comment._content: Although you've listed her as a chemist, it appears that she was a zoologist/biologist. Some more information about her: She was born on 2 Sep 1884 at Au Sable, Chasm, NY. Her parents were William J Hayden & Catherina Alger Hayden. Name:Margaret Alger Hayden Birth Date:2 Sep 1884 Birth Place:Au Sable, Chasm, New York Age:38 Residence:Ashland, Massachusetts Passport Issue Date:4 Jun 1923 Father Name:William C Hayden, deceased Father's Birth Location:Rutland, Vermont [source: National Archives and Records Administration (NARA), Washington D.C.; Passport Applications, January 2, 1906 - March 31, 1925; Microfilm Serial: M1490;Roll #2291.] In the 1920 US Census, she was listed in Wellesley, Ma, as a teacher at Wellesley College. She lived with her widowed mother, Catherine Hayden, and her widowed grandmother Frances Alger. Going further back, we find that Frances Alger was the wife of William J. Alger, a clergyman. [Source Citation: Year: 1880; Census Place: Saco, York, Maine; Roll: 491; Family History Film: 1254491; Page: 531B; Enumeration District: 205; Image: 0804.] Her doctoral thesis was published in 1924: Karyosphere formation and synapsis in Phanaeus Author:Margaret Alger Hayden Publisher:Wellesley, Mass., 1924. Dissertation:Thesis (Ph. D.)--Columbia university, 1924. [source: worldcat] The abstract of her thesis can be found here online library of wiley She retired from Wellesley College in June 1950, after 32 years of service. [source: Report of the President of Wellesley College 1949-50 ] In 1961, she was listed as an Emeritus Member of the American Society of Zoologists [source: Amer. Zool. (1961) 1 (4): 538-539.] According to the Social Security Administration, Margaret Hayden passed away in Jan 1969.

comment.author: 25053835@N03
comment._content:
Hi Brenda-

This is some incredibly detailed information! Thank you very much, especially for the detailed citations. I'm passing it along to our archivists now.

Best,
Catherine Shteynberg
